This text was transcribed using whisper model: large-v2

 And I will be continuing the AITM discussion from a slightly different perspective.
So we will be unravelling the threat landscape, so where we are when it comes to AITM.
But also I will teach you about how can we detect and prevent those types of attacks
from the blue team perspective.
Before I introduce myself, I wanted to thank my V-team that works tirelessly on the AITM
TTP detections and threat actor attribution.
This deck wouldn't be possible without anonymous heroes from MISTIC, Defender for Experts team.
And my name is Paweł Partyka, I'm just the messenger in some of the aspects of this presentation.
I work as the security researcher at Microsoft in the Defender XDR, or I used to work until
June 1st, with my focus area on adversary in the middle and business email compromise.
So last around three years, I have been working with my team on identifying the patterns of
ways to detect AITM using Defender XDR capabilities.
So it's not about preventing email delivery, it's about what happens afterwards.
So what happens when the user actually signs in, what are the signals that we can leverage
to detect AITM or consequence of AITM, which is very often business email compromise.
And we didn't stop there, we continued, okay, we just don't want to alert customers about
the fact that there was someone falling prey to AITM.
We also wanted to automatically disrupt those attacks, so more on that later.
I recently moved to GHOST, which is Global Hunting Oversight Strategic Triaging, very
long name, so I will be more working on threat intel, but for this conversation, let's focus
on Defender XDR capabilities.
And I'm based in Switzerland.
So the agenda is very straightforward.
First of all, I will introduce you to the threat landscape.
What is the situation when it comes to different actors on the AITM market?
What are the different indicators that those AITM phishing kids leave that you can maybe
hunt for in your environments?
And finally, what are the detection and prevention mechanisms that you can implement?
All right, so the threat overview adversary in the middle, credential phishing.
What we have seen in the last couple of years is that some of the threat actors have learned
that they can actually work less and reduce the risk of exposure by providing tools and
services and support instead of conducting the full-fledged attacks.
So they basically license the tools for a fee to affiliates, which either pay for the
service or participate in the profit sharing.
This trend led to release of several phishing-as-a-service offerings that I will be highlighting today.
And basically, it meant that the segmentation of the cybercrime economy led to democratization
and reduced the barrier of entry for even low-skilled cybercriminals to start phishing
using advanced techniques.
So this ease of deploying certain phishing-as-a-service solutions meant that every unsophisticated
threat actor could now start using and collecting session cookies and replaying them against
victims that even had multifactor authentication.
We see that most of the attacks are opportunistic rather than targeted, though we also see nation-state
actors using some of the phishing-as-a-service solutions.
And they follow the traditional pattern, right?
So there would be a threat actor would craft an initial email with a lure, and that would,
when clicked, lead to another threat party, usually intermediary website, with another
lure, and then only the victim will land on the phishing AITM website.
So a little bit of history.
Where did we start and where are we now?
So Evil Jinx was released in 2017, version 1.0.
It is an open-source, free-to-use tool, but it was mainly used by red teamers, right?
We didn't see AITM being the most important type of phishing tool or phishing capability
until basically 2021, when Evil Proxy came to the market, and this really reshuffled
the market.
A lot of threat actors that were launching traditional types of phishing actually shifted
towards AITM.
This was the first phishing-as-a-service release with extremely powerful support capabilities
and extremely good tutorials, how to configure it, how to use it.
So the people that were basically joining the community of being phishing threat actors
could easily ramp up and start phishing using high-volume campaigns.
Of course, probably the profit margins that authors of Evil Proxy achieved encouraged
other cybercriminals to join.
And in 2022, another very prolific and popular phishing kit was released, Naked Pages.
In 2022, for the first time, we blogged as a Microsoft about this phenomena, and in relation
to business email compromise that often follows AITM campaigns.
There were other actors that were joining, Greatness, Phishing Kit, Caffeine transitioned
from traditional phishing to the AITM.
So nowadays, basically, we see that the traditional phishing, even though it still exists, it
is less prolific than leverage of AITM-capable kits, right?
So now more than 50% of phishing attacks already leverages AITM.
That's, of course, also because more and more organizations deployed MFA.
So now I wanted to deep dive a little bit into different AITM types, right?
I'm not sure if you are familiar with the fact that actually we can distinguish between
two of them.
One is Standard Reverse Proxy, and the other one is Synchronous Relay.
So let's start with Standard Reverse Proxy, which Evil Jinx is representative of.
So basically, in this type of AITM, the session is proxied and traverses through the VPS,
or Virtual Private Server, that hosts the phishing kit.
And there are two TLS sessions established between the victim and the phishing server,
and then phishing server and the identity provider, such as Okta, Entry, Yahoo, iCloud,
whatever the operator of the phishing kit wants to target.
And of course, the MFA session is transmitted back to the victim.
Victim completes the MFA, and then when the identity provider sends the cookie back,
then they can be captured on the phishing server.
So a couple of examples of the phishing kits that are in this category.
Of course, Evil Jinx.
We also track Evil Jinx as a service offering.
We don't have a threat actor group name assigned to it.
We identify threat actor groups by storm and four digits.
We identify them right now by this YWNLB code name,
which is because they often use this as a host name in the URL of the phishing site that they launch.
And the most prolific nowadays phishing kit that is a reverse proxy is Storm 0835 Evil Proxy.
I'm not sure how many of you have heard about it.
There were multiple blogs, not only from Microsoft, but from other security vendors about it.
We also attribute naked pages to the reverse proxy kits, but it's actually not one.
It just behaves like one.
You can also think of serverless functions such as Cloudflare workers, Azure functions as standard reverse proxies.
So now let's try to understand what patterns each of these kits actually leaves.
And as I said, I will not focus on the email or URL structure, rather on what is actually in the sign-in logs.
So every of these kits need to sign in the victim to the identity provider.
So we in Defender XDR use a magnitude of signals from different products, including EntroID.
And actually EntroID is a very good source of intelligence about the fact that there might be an AITM sign-in taking place.
So everything by default signs you in into the office home resource by pretending to be an office home application.
What is very important and fundamental for all the standard reverse proxy kits, which is the fact that the device remote connection IP address,
so the victim's destination IP address, so the IP address to which the victim will connect,
we will see the same IP address in the sign-in logs in EntroID or Okta or whatever identity provider.
So this is not super unusual, because if you use Zscaler or other web proxy, you might terminate the session, you would observe the same.
But if you combine the fact that this IP address matching happens and the sign-in takes place from unfamiliar location,
from using unfamiliar user agent, unfamiliar browser, you might have a detection right for that.
And also I couldn't figure out why, but in some of the cases we can identify the phishing site URL in the referrer field in the sign-in log.
So if your identity provider allows you to capture referrer field, you can see what was the phishing website that initiated the sign-in.
And the fun fact, the default evasion or redirection to the Rick Astley already generated 1.5 billion views for that YouTube video.
Okay, let's switch gears towards Everyproxy.
So as you can see here, the sign-in pattern is completely different.
The Everyproxy by default signs you in into Office 365 or pretends to be Office 365 application,
and the resource is empty, which is already unusual.
Normally when you sign in to any resource, you would have the resource name in the sign-in logs.
Again, device remote connection IP matches the identity provider facing IP address.
The interesting enrichment into Everyproxy's capabilities was autoclick of keep me signing.
So the victim doesn't need to select, yes, no, do you want to stay signed in?
They do it on behalf of the victim, so it means that the operator of the phishing kit will get a persistent cookie.
That's the goal.
And they redirect to example.com after victim completes the process.
By default, we land on this page, so if you see a connection in your web proxy logs to example.com,
you can now go and do reverse engineering why this user actually connected to it.
It's not like an unusual site that users might be opening.
They also added another interesting capability, which is refreshing of the stolen cookies.
So when they capture it on behalf of the operator, owner of the phishing kit,
they will periodically use the stolen cookie to refresh it and gain a new with an extended validation time or validity time.
They use it against, again, Office 365 application and very unusual OAuth endpoint will be called.
Org ID WS Federation, so again, if you're signing logs, whatever your identity provider is,
provides you with the OAuth call information, be on the lookout for this sign-in,
especially when your domain, your UPN domain of your users is not federated.
Then that would be already a red flag for sure.
And we see that Evil Proxy, this actually varies.
These are statistics from last 40 days.
They are typically hosted on GhostNet, Hostinger and DigitalOcean providers.
And you can see on Telegram, they already have 3,375 subscribers.
Naked Pages actually has more, 4,700.
They use Exchange Online as the destination.
They redirect the victim to Microsoft Privacy Statement site.
Again, the remote connection IP address will match the IDP-facing IP address.
And they host, the Naked Pages installations are most often hosted on DigitalOcean, Akamai, Datasource, Atlantic.
And they often also, actually this is on the operator site, on the Fisher site,
to protect the installation of the Naked Pages with Cloudflare turnstile.
And we can see, they also customize this message, why you need to complete this turnstile.
And sometimes they do grammatical mistakes.
We need to review the security of your connection before proceeding.
This is exactly how it should be written.
Fun fact, on May 26th, according to the announcement on the Telegram channel, they ceased operation.
So they completely shut down after being operational for two years.
And then on the same day, someone also opened a new Telegram channel
and started inviting all the Naked Pages customers to join Sakai Pages, new offering.
Very similar characteristics, we are still learning if there's any difference.
There was initial discounted price for new joiners, for new customers or transitioning customers.
I didn't manage to capture what was the discount, I have just the current prices.
Okay, so now let's move on to Synchronous Relay.
So this is more complicated, also from Defender's point of view, I must say.
The infrastructure is slightly more complicated.
So the victim will connect to the VPS, or Virtual Private Server, where the phishing kit is running.
And then through API that the phishing kit master server, let's say, central server,
or phishing as a service platform provides, there will be a communication.
And then this would be relayed to the phishing as a service platform
that then would connect on behalf of the VPS to the identity provider.
And this is how the communication will go.
So there will be one more intermediary step in the entire communication chain.
You might think, okay, if there's a centralized platform that performs the signings
on behalf of all those affiliate servers, it might be easy to narrow down the list of IP addresses
that they use and just blacklist them on the identity provider side.
But actually, they use residential proxy very often.
So there isn't static list of IP addresses that they use.
They continuously rotate the IP addresses, even if you...
So the more sophisticated keys, such as Caffeine, I think Tycoon as well,
even if you use the same phishing installation and the same user,
every time you will get different IP address in your signing logs, right?
So every time they rotate it, which is good from the attack success perspective.
The examples, Tycoon, Greatness, Caffeine, worth mentioning right now,
and Rockstar 2FA, also known as .sec.
These are the main actors.
Tycoon, very interesting characteristics in designing pattern.
I mean, they rotate the user agent, right?
So they use actually static user agent.
So every couple of weeks, they change it.
As you can see, on May 8th, they updated the Chrome version to 1.2.4.
And then since June 6th, we observed completely different user agent axios.
We are still trying to understand why they send such an unpopular user agent.
What's the idea here?
And they sign in victims to Office Home by default.
So similar to Evil Jinx.
And again, many times, the sites are protected with Cloudflare town style.
Caffeine, another very interesting actor.
What is unique about them is that they use different user agent for login part,
when you enter your username and password,
and then there will be different user agent when you complete MFA.
So also unusual, because when legitimate user performs a sign-in,
there will be the same user agent in all the sign-in requests.
Application, again, Office Home.
And some obsolete IOCs.
For Greatness, they use static correlation ID and static nonce.
We already rotated them last year.
So that's a summary of what are the characteristics of phishing kits.
The most popular ones that we observed,
the most popular phishing as a service offerings.
So I think this is what we already discussed.
This is the only one that leverages Office 365 App ID.
Okay, so let's switch gears and now let's talk about
the AITM prevention. What can you do to prevent AITM attacks?

of course, investment in advanced anti-phishing solution that scans actively
the sites is a must-have.
Many vendors don't actually use their own IP addresses that

as well, just to blend in better into the
regular traffic. But from the identity point of view,
this enables conditional access policies. There are multiple things

So with traditional phishing, those would be ineffective.

you can actually enable Enter ID
conditional access policies. For example, risk-based access policies.
What are the risk-based access policies?
